bboxes.raw_text:
The VNB publication points out
that figures on tourist and travel
spending are estimates--"based
on sampling studies and other In
formation that includes rental In
come, restaurant sales, sales
of motor vehicle fuel and also a
liberal measure of guestimat-
ting


Motorists who pause for an
overnight stay. or longer, add
much more to the states econ
omy than those who see Arizona
only as a place to be got across
as quickly as possible.


Each car that travels straight
across the state--with no stops
except for fuel or food--repre-
sents spending of about $40, Ari-
iona Progress estimates, adding:


"We estimate that the daily
expenditure per auto by motorists
who sight-see and stay overnight
in Arizona approMmates $685."

Arthur ARROW passed away
June 80. Final arrangements are
pending.


Sammie Warren, Of Los An
geles, was elected to Pacific
States president.


Mrs. Bessie l. Smith was re-
elected president of the women's
division.


Alva Griffin won the SIS rattle.


Arizona daughters receiving
Past State President honors were
Charlesetta McClammy. Mary
Boozer, Of Phoenix, and Joyce
Neal. of Flagstaff. Mrs. Neal
won her PDR honors.

Arizona was visited by more
out-of-state motorists than last
year. A total of 4,l63.325 cars
entered the state. The estimated
spending by tourists and trav-
elers reached the all-time high
Of $375 million.


These estimates were made by
the research department Of the
Valley National Bank and was
published in the banks monthly
business review, Arizona Pro-
gress.


1.-THE out-of-state motorists,
of course, add to Arizona S high
way traffic problems" the bank
report states. "They also, how
ever. provide Arizona with an
important source of income.


sit is no coincidence that as
the number of cars entering the
state has increased, the total
dollars spent in Arizona by tour
lists and travellers has increased
also"

Vernon Mathews, 8. wears a
pleased expression as he surveys
all of the lovely birthday gifts
he received.


The son of Mr.. and Mrs. Her
man Mathews, ITO w. Mohave,
Vernon was honored by relatives
and friends at party.


Guests included Chris May
field, Dennis Bobo, Arthur Mil
Ter, Bobby Carrethers, Debra
James, Veronica Jack, Linda
Owens, Debra and Calvin Will
liams, Gwendolyn Calvin, Ester
and Andrew Tadamy, Joe Brown,
Victor Doss, and Berney Gre
sham.

Walter Tucker, IT, 1919 E.
Pueblo, owner of a restaurant
was seriously wounded by a shot
fired by Thomas Duncan. 10. l07
S. 18th St.


Tucker was shot in fuckers
Inn, 1901 E. Jefferson St. He
staggered from the inn and drove
himself home. He was admitted
to Memorial Hospital with a bull
let wound through the left chest.
above the heart.


Duncan was arrested for
carrying a concealed weapon and
assault with a deadly weapon.

Wood rolling pins, pastry boards,
spoons, and other cooking Access
series may be safely immersed in
soap or detergent suds for wash
ing = but should not be left to
soak. After rinsing and wiping,
let such utensils air-dry before
putting them away.

Sarah Folsom, Yavapai County
School superintendent for the past
IL years, and a member of the
State Board of Education, an
nounced she will seek the office
Of State Superintendent of Public
Instruction on the Republican IT,
ket.


Mrs. Folsom stated "Since the
announcement of the Draft Sarah
Folsom committee a few days
ago, Ihave heard from Republican
and Democratic friends from all
IA counties urging me to run for
the office Of State Superintendent
of Public Instruction. will take
my campaign, based on my deep
beliefs in quality education and
my record in Arizona Public
School Administration, to the
people Of this great state. If they
see fit to place me in this office
of high responsibility and trust,
will carry out faithfully,
diligently and impartially 1.-THE
duties Of the office as outlined in
the Arizona Statutes. l will
always place the child first and
the taxpayer close second. My
objective Is the best possible
education for each child so that
the childs personalities may be
developed. The Strengthening of
fundamentals (the 8 R's), more
equal educational opportunities
for children. the raising Of edu-
cational standards, the emphasi-
zing of American history COM
prise my specific aims


furthermore" Mrs. Folsom
commented: "The record an
elective official makes while in
office is a good indication of what
citizens can expect Of that Off
cial. AS to my sense of fiscal
responsibility. feel that taxes
come from all people. Tax
monies should be spent with the
utmost discretion. indeed with
more care than when spending
ones own money.


Immediately upon assuming Of
flee as County School Superin-
tendent, Mrs. Folsom s efficient
management of money allowed
each child in Yavapai County
nearly $1,000 more in per capita
aid.


New Subscription

Mrs. Folsom
Seeks Stuie
Education Post

ST. LOUIS-The Rev. John ].
Hicks, president of the board of
education resigned to become
pastor of ST. Marks Methodist
Church in New York City.


MIR. Hicks, first Negro to serve
as school board president, has
been on the board since 1859.
He served as pastor of Union
Memorial Methodist Church, the
largest Methodist congregation in
St. Louis.


The minister was the first Ne
gro to win a citywide election.

NEW YORK--In an effort to
keep the highly praised play by
James Baldwin. "Blues for MIR.
CHARLIE from closing, the
NAACP has strongly urged its
members to see the perform
ance.


In a letter to NAACP mem
bers in the greater New York
area. Roy wilkins, executive Sec
rotary, said. sit would be a gen
uine misfortune If this play went
under. 1t Is dramatic and percep-
tive, and sometimes shocking"


In urging their patr onage. MIR.
wilkins commented that the play
IDEALS with issues which are
basic to the fight in which we
are engaged"


The play has received excel
lent reviews, but attendance fig
ures have not been high enough
to insure long run. A contri-
button of several thousand dollars
has enabled 1t to keep running
fhus far.
